033    /** Used to prevent massive debug dumps. See {@link #getDisplayString(String, String)} */
034    private static final int MAX_STRING_OUTPUT_CHARS = 300;
035
036        /** Left-justification constant for use in the {@link #pad(String, int, int)} method */
037        public static final int JUSTIFICATION_LEFT = 0;
038        
039        /** Center-justification constant for use in the {@link #pad(String, int, int)} method */
040        public static final int JUSTIFICATION_CENTER = 1;
041
042        /** Right-justification constant for use in the {@link #pad(String, int, int)} method */
043        public static final int JUSTIFICATION_RIGHT = 2;

045        public static Pattern scriptPattern = Pattern.compile("<(/script)", Pattern.CASE_INSENSITIVE);

047    /** Returns true if the supplied string is null or the empty string, false otherwise
048     *
049     * @param text The string to test
050     * @return true if the supplied string is null or the empty string, false otherwise
051     */
052    public static boolean isBlank(String text) {
053        return (text == null || text.equals(""));
054    }
055
056    /** Returns true if the supplied string is non-null and only contains numeric characters
057     *
058     * @param text The string to test
059     * @return true if the supplied string is non-null and only contains numeric characters
060     */
061    public static boolean isNumeric(String text) {
062        if (text == null) {
063            return false;
064        }
065        char ch;
066        for (int i = 0; i < text.length(); i++) {
067            ch = text.charAt(i);
068            if (ch < '0' || ch > '9') {
069                return false;
070            }
071        }
072        return true;
073    }
074
075    /** Returns true if the supplied string is non-null and only contains numeric characters
076    * or a single decimal point. The value can have a leading negative ('-') symbol.
077    * 
078    * @param text The string to test
079    * @return true if the supplied string is non-null and only contains numeric characters,
080    *   which may contain a '.' character in there somewhere.
081    */
082   public static boolean isNumericDecimal(String text) {
083       if (text == null) {
084           return false;
085       }
086       boolean seenPoint = false; // existential quandary there for you
087       char ch;
088       int len = text.length();
089       for (int i = 0; i < len; i++) {
090           ch = text.charAt(i);
091           if (ch=='.') {
092                   if (seenPoint) { return false; }
093                   seenPoint = true;
094           } else if (ch == '-' && i == 0) {
095                   // leading negative symbol OK
096                   if (len == 1) {
097                           // but not if it's the only character in the string
098                           return false;
099                   }
100           } else if (ch < '0' || ch > '9') {
101               return false;
102           }
103       }
104       return true;
105   }
106
107     /** Returns true if the supplied string is non-null and only contains numeric characters
108     * or a single decimal point. The value can have a leading negative ('-') symbol.
109     * 
110     * This version allows exponents ("E+nn" or "E-nn") to the end of the value.
111     * 
112     * @param text The string to test
113     * @return true if the supplied string is non-null and only contains numeric characters,
114     *  which may contain a '.' character in there somewhere.
115     */
116    public static boolean isNumericDecimalExp(String text) {
117        if (text == null) {
118          return false;
119        }
120            boolean seenPoint = false; // existential quandary there for you
121            int expPos = -1;           // position of the 'E' character
122            char ch;
123            for (int i = 0; i < text.length(); i++) {
124                ch = text.charAt(i);
125                if (ch=='E') {
126                        if (expPos != -1) { return false; }
127                        expPos = i;
128                } else if (ch=='.' && expPos == -1) {
129                if (seenPoint) { return false; }
130                seenPoint = true;
131                } else if ((ch == '+' || ch == '-') && i == expPos + 1) {
132                        // + or - directly after 'E' OK
133            } else if (ch == '-' && i == 0) {
134                // leading negative symbol OK
135            } else if (ch < '0' || ch > '9') {
136                return false;
137            }
138            }
139            return true;
140    }
141
142
143    /** Ensures that a string returned from a browser (on any platform) conforms
144     * to unix line-EOF conventions. Any instances of consecutive CRs (<code>0xD</code>) 
145     * and LFs (<code>0xA</code>) in a string will be reduced to a series of CRs (the number of CRs will be the
146     * maximum number of CRs or LFs found in a row).  
147     * 
148     * @param input the input string
149     * 
150     * @return the canonicalised string, as described above
151     */
152    public static String reduceNewlines(String input) {
153        StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder();
154        int len = input.length();
155        int crCount = 0;
156                int lfCount = 0;
157                boolean insertNewline = false;
158                char ch;
159        for (int i=0; i<len; i++) {
160                ch = input.charAt(i);
161                if (ch == (char) 0xA) {
162                        lfCount ++; insertNewline = true;
163                } else if (ch == (char) 0xD) {
164                        crCount ++; insertNewline = true;
165                } else if (insertNewline) {
166                                for (int j=0; j<Math.max(lfCount, crCount); j++) {
167                                        sb.append((char) 0xA);
168                                }
169                                insertNewline = false; lfCount=0; crCount=0;
170                                sb.append(ch);
171                } else {
172                        sb.append(ch);
173                }
174        }
175        if (insertNewline) {
176                        for (int j=0; j<Math.max(lfCount, crCount); j++) {
177                                sb.append((char) 0xA);
178                        }
179        }
180        
181        return sb.toString();
182    }
183
184
185    /**
186     * Returns the HTML-escaped form of a string. The <code>&amp;</code>,
187     * <code>&lt;</code>, <code>&gt;</code>, and <code>"</code> characters are converted to
188     * <code>&amp;amp;</code>, <code>&amp;lt;</code>, <code>&amp;gt;</code>, and
189     * <code>&amp;quot;</code> respectively.
190     * 
191     * <p>Characters in the unicode control code blocks ( apart from \t, \n and \r ) are converted to &amp;xfffd;
192     * <p>Characters outside of the ASCII printable range are converted into &amp;xnnnn; form
193     *
194     * @param string the string to convert
195     *
196     * @return the HTML-escaped form of the string
197     */
198    static public String escapeHtml(String string) {
199        if (string == null) {
200            return "";
201        }
202        char c;
203        String hex;
204        StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder(string.length());
205        for (int i = 0; i < string.length(); i++) {
206            c = string.charAt(i);
207            // check for illegal characters
208            switch (c) {
209                case '&':
210                    sb.append("&amp;");
211                    break;
212                case '<':
213                    sb.append("&lt;");
214                    break;
215                case '>':
216                    sb.append("&gt;");
217                    break;
218                case '\"':
219                    // interestingly, &quote; (with the e) works fine for HTML display,
220                    // but not inside hidden field values
221                    sb.append("&quot;");
222                    break;
223                default:
224                        // 'illegal characters' according to ESAPI. 7f to 9f are control characters in unicode 
225                        if ( ( c <= 0x1f && c != '\t' && c != '\n' && c != '\r' ) || ( c >= 0x7f && c <= 0x9f ) ) {
226                                sb.append("&#xfffd;"); // REPLACEMENT_HEX in ESAPI's HtmlEntityCodec
227                        } else if ( c > 0x1f && c <= 0x7f ) {
228                                // safe printable
229                                sb.append(c);
230                        } else {
231                                // ESAPI didn't have the else block above, which was causing it escape everything 
232                                hex = getHexForNonAlphanumeric(c);
233                                sb.append("&#x" + hex + ";");
234                        }
235                        
236            }
237        }
238
239        return sb.toString();
240    }
241
242    /**
243     * Returns the unescaped version of a string. 
244     * Converts &amp;amp; &amp;lt; and &amp;gt; entities to their
245     * characters
246     * 
247     * @TODO all those other ones
248     *
249     * @param string The string to be unescaped.
250     * @return The unescaped version of the string.
251     */
252    private String unescapeHtml(String string)
253    {
254        string = string.replaceAll("&amp;", "&");
255        string = string.replaceAll("&lt;", "<");
256        string = string.replaceAll("&gt;", ">");
257        return string;
258    }    
259    
260    /**
261     * Returns a regex-escaped form of a string. That is, the pattern 
262     * returned by this method, if compiled into a regex, will match
263     * the supplied string exactly. 
264     *
265     * @param string the string to convert
266     *
267     * @return the HTML-escaped form of the string
268     */
269    static public String escapeRegex(String string) {
270        if (string == null) {
271            return "";
272        }
273
274        char c;
275        StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder(string.length());
276
277        for (int i = 0; i < string.length(); i++) {
278            c = string.charAt(i);
279
280            switch (c) {
281                case '.':
282                case '+': // intentional fall-through
283                case '?': // intentional fall-through
284                case '\\': // intentional fall-through
285                case '{': // intentional fall-through
286                case '}': // intentional fall-through
287                case '[': // intentional fall-through
288                case ']': // intentional fall-through
289                case '^': // intentional fall-through
290                case '$': // intentional fall-through
291                case '(': // intentional fall-through
292                case '|': // intentional fall-through
293                case ')': // intentional fall-through
294                        sb.append("\\");
295                    sb.append(c);
296                    break;
297                default:
298                    sb.append(c);
299            }
300        }
301
302        return sb.toString();
303    }
304    
305    
306    /**
307     * Returns the csv-escaped form of a string. A csv-escaped string is
308     * used when writing to a CSV (comma-separated-value) file. It ensures
309     * that commas included within a string are quoted. We use the Microsoft-Excel
310     * quoting rules, so that our CSV files can be imported into that. These rules
311     * (derived from experimentation) are:
312     *
313     * <ul>
314     * <li>Strings without commas (,) inverted commas ("), or newlines (\n) are returned as-is.
315     * <li>Otherwise, the string is surrounded by inverted commas, and any
316     *   inverted commas within the string are doubled-up (i.e. '"' becomes '""').
317     * <li>A value that starts with any of "=", "@", "+" or "-" has a leading single apostrophe added
318     *   to prevent the value being evaluated in Excel. The leading quote is visible to the user when the
319     *   csv is opened, which may mean that it will have to be removed when roundtripping data.
320     *   This may complicate things if the user actually wants a leading single quote in their CSV value.   
321     * </ul>
322     *
323     * <p>Embedded newlines are inserted as-is, as per Excel. This will require
324     * some care whilst parsing if we want to be able to read these files.
325     *
326     * @param string the string to convert
327     *
328     * @return the csv-escaped form of the string
329     */
330    static public String escapeCsv(String string) {
331        if (string == null) {
332            return "";
333        }
334
335        boolean quoted = false;
336        // from https://www.contextis.com/en/blog/comma-separated-vulnerabilities
337        // prefix cells that start with ‘=’ , '@', '+' or '-' with an apostrophe 
338        // This will ensure that the cell isn’t interpreted as a formula, and as a bonus in Microsoft Excel the apostrophe itself will not be displayed.
339        if (string.startsWith("=") || 
340          string.startsWith("@")) {
341            // prefix the string with an a single quote char to escape it
342            string = "'" + string;
343            quoted = true; // not sure need to quote here, but doesn't hurt
344        } else if ((string.startsWith("+") || string.startsWith("-")) && 
345                (string.length() == 1 || !Text.isNumericDecimalExp(string))) {
346                // numbers can legitimately start with '+' or '-' but anything else should be escaped
347                string = "'" + string;
348            quoted = true; 
349        }
350
351        
352        if (string.indexOf(',') == -1 && string.indexOf('"') == -1 && string.indexOf('\n') == -1 && !quoted) {
353                return string;
354        }
355        string = Text.replaceString(string, "\"", "\"\"");
356        string = "\"" + string + "\"";
357
358        return string;
359    }
360
361    /** Given a csv-encoded string (as produced by the rules in {@link #escapeCsv(String)},
362     *  produces a List of Strings which represent the individual values in the string.
363     *  Note that this method is *not* equivalent to calling <code>Arrays.asList(astring.split(","))</code>.
364     *
365     * <p>Setting the whitespaceSensitive parameter to false allows leading and trailing
366     * whitespace in *non-quoted* values to be removed, e.g. if the input string <code>text</code> is:
367     *
368     * <pre class="code">
369     * abc,def,  ghi, j k ,"lmn"," op "," q,r","""hello""", "another"
370     * </pre>
371     *
372     * then <code>parseCsv(text, <b>false</b>)</code> will return the strings:
373     * <pre class="code">
374     * abc
375     * def
376     * ghi
377     * j k
378     * lmn
379     *  op        <i>(this String has one leading space, and a trailing space after 'p')</i>
380     *  q,r       <i>(this String has one leading space)</i>
381     * "hello"
382     * another
383     * </pre>
384     *
385     * and <code>parseCsv(text, <b>true</b>)</code> would throw a ParseException (since the
386     * final element is a quoted value, but begins with a space).
387     *
388     * If the <code>, "another"</code> text is removed, however, then
389     * <code>parseCsv(text, true)</code> would return the following:
390     *
391     * and <code>parseCsv(text, true)</code> will return the string
392     * <pre>
393     * abc
394     * def
395     *   ghi      <i>(this String has two leading spaces)</i>
396     *  j k       <i>(this String has one leading space and a trailing space after the 'k' character)</i>
397     * lmn
398     *  op        <i>(this String has one leading space, and a trailing space after 'p')</i>
399     *  q,r       <i>(this String has one leading space)</i>
400     * "hello"
401     * </pre>
402     *
403     * <p>Most applications would want to use the 'whiteSpaceSensitive=false' form of this function, since
404     * (a) less chance of a ParseException, and (b) it's what an end-user would normally
405     * expect. This can be performed by calling the {@link #parseCsv(String)} method.
406     *
407     * <p>Whitespace is determined by using the <code>Character.isSpaceChar()</code> method,
408     * which is Unicode-aware.
409     *
410     * @param text   The CSV-encoded string to parse
411     * @param whitespaceSensitive   If set to true, will trim leading and trailing whitespace in *non-quoted* values.
412     *
413     * @return a List of Strings. The returned List is guaranteed to always contain at least one element.
414     *
415     * @throws NullPointerException if the text passed to this method is null
416     * @throws ParseException if a quoted value contains leading whitespace before the
417     *  opening quote, or after the trailing quote.
418     * @throws ParseException if a quoted value has a start quote, but no end quote, or
419     *   if a value has additional text after a quoted value (before the next comma or EOL).
420     */
421    static public List<String> parseCsv(String text, boolean whitespaceSensitive)
422        throws ParseException {
423        if (text == null) {
424            throw new NullPointerException("null text");
425        }
426
427        // parse state: 
428        //   0=searching for new value (at start of line or after comma) 
429        //   1=consuming non-quoted values
430        //   2=consuming quoted value
431        //   3=consumed first quote within a quoted value (may be termining quote or a "" sequence)
432        //   4=consuming whitespace up to next comma/EOL (after quoted value, not whitespaceSensitive)
433        int parseState = 0;
434        int length = text.length();
435        String element;
436        List<String> result = new ArrayList<String>();
437        char ch;
438        StringBuilder buffer = new StringBuilder();
439
440        for (int pos = 0; pos < length; pos++) {
441            ch = text.charAt(pos);
442
443            // System.out.println("pos " + pos + ", state=" + parseState + ", nextchar=" + ch + ", buf=" + buffer);
444            switch (parseState) {
445                case 0:
446                    if (Character.isSpaceChar(ch)) {
447                        if (whitespaceSensitive) {
448                            buffer.append(ch);
449                            parseState = 1;
450                        } else {
451                            // ignore
452                        }
453                    } else if (ch == '"') {
454                        parseState = 2;
455                    } else if (ch == ',') {
456                        result.add(""); // add an empty element; state remains unchanged
457                    } else {
458                        buffer.append(ch);
459                        parseState = 1;
460                    }
461                    break;
462                case 1:
463                    if (ch == ',') {
464                        element = buffer.toString();
465                        if (!whitespaceSensitive) {
466                            element = element.trim();
467                        }
468                        result.add(element);
469                        buffer.setLength(0);
470                        parseState = 0;
471                    } else {
472                        buffer.append(ch);
473                    }
474                    break;
475                case 2:
476                    if (ch == '"') {
477                        parseState = 3;
478                    } else {
479                        buffer.append(ch);
480                    }
481                    break;
482                case 3:
483                    if (ch == '"') {
484                        buffer.append('"');
485                        parseState = 2;
486                    } else if (ch == ',') {
487                        result.add(buffer.toString());
488                        buffer.setLength(0);
489                        parseState = 0;
490                    } else if (Character.isSpaceChar(ch)) {
491                        if (whitespaceSensitive) {
492                            throw new ParseException("Cannot have trailing whitespace after close quote character", pos);
493                        }
494                        parseState = 4;
495                    } else {
496                        throw new ParseException("Cannot have trailing data after close quote character", pos);
497                    }
498                    break;
499                case 4:
500                    if (Character.isSpaceChar(ch)) {
501                        // consume and ignore
502                    } else if (ch == ',') {
503                        result.add(buffer.toString());
504                        buffer.setLength(0);
505                        parseState = 0;
506                    } else {
507                        throw new ParseException("Cannot have trailing data after close quote character", pos);
508                    }
509                    break;
510                    
511                default:
512                    throw new IllegalStateException("Illegal state '" + parseState + "' in parseCsv");
513            }
514        }
515
516        // if state is 2, we are in the middle of a quoted value
517        if (parseState == 2) {
518            throw new ParseException("Missing endquote in csv text", length);
519        }
520
521        // otherwise we still need to add what's left in the buffer into the result list
522        element = buffer.toString();
523        if (parseState == 1 && !whitespaceSensitive) {
524            element = element.trim();
525        }
526        result.add(element);
527        return result;
528    }
529    
530    @FunctionalInterface
531    public interface CsvLineReader { // doesn't extend Supplier<T> as it throws exceptions
532        /** Returns the next logical line in the CSV ( quoted values can contain newlines )  
533         * 
534         * @return
535         * @throws ParseException
536         * @throws IOException
537         */
538        List<String> readLine() throws ParseException, IOException;
539    }
540    
541    // same as parseCsv(String, whitespaceSensitive) but can handle newlines in quotes by supplying a Reader
542    // the returned object will return a List<String> or null if EOF is reached
543    // ParseExceptions are wrapped in something, probably
544    static public CsvLineReader parseCsv(Reader r, boolean whitespaceSensitive) {
545        if (r == null) {
546            throw new NullPointerException("null reader");
547        }
548        return new CsvLineReader() {
549                // eof if we actually read eof or encouner a parse exception ( cannot recover )
550                boolean isEOF = false;
551                        @Override
552                        public List<String> readLine() throws ParseException, IOException {
553                                // first read is never null
554                                if (isEOF) { return null; }
555                                
556                                // parse state: 
557                        //   0=searching for new value (at start of line or after comma) 
558                        //   1=consuming non-quoted values
559                        //   2=consuming quoted value
560                        //   3=consumed first quote within a quoted value (may be termining quote or a "" sequence)
561                        //   4=consuming whitespace up to next comma/EOL (after quoted value, not whitespaceSensitive)
562                        int parseState = 0;
563                        // int length = text.length();
564                        String element;
565                        List<String> result = new ArrayList<String>();
566                        char ch;
567                        StringBuilder buffer = new StringBuilder();
568                        int intChar = r.read();
569                        int pos = 1;
570
571                        // @TODO better CRLF handling
572                        while (intChar != -1) {
573                            ch = (char) intChar;
574
575                            // System.out.println("pos " + pos + ", state=" + parseState + ", nextchar=" + ch + ", buf=" + buffer);
576                            switch (parseState) {
577                                case 0:
578                                        if (ch == '\n') {
579                                                // return result so far
580                                                element = buffer.toString();
581                                                result.add(buffer.toString());
582                                                return result;
583                                        } else if (Character.isSpaceChar(ch)) {
584                                        if (whitespaceSensitive) {
585                                            buffer.append(ch);
586                                            parseState = 1;
587                                        } else {
588                                            // ignore
589                                        }
590                                    } else if (ch == '"') {
591                                        parseState = 2;
592                                    } else if (ch == ',') {
593                                        result.add(""); // add an empty element; state remains unchanged
594                                    } else {
595                                        buffer.append(ch);
596                                        parseState = 1;
597                                    }
598                                    break;
599                                case 1:
600                                        if (ch == '\n') {
601                                                // return result so far
602                                                element = buffer.toString();
603                                                if (!whitespaceSensitive) {
604                                                    element = element.trim();
605                                                }
606                                                result.add(buffer.toString());
607                                                return result;
608                                        } else if (ch == ',') {
609                                        element = buffer.toString();
610                                        if (!whitespaceSensitive) {
611                                            element = element.trim();
612                                        }
613                                        result.add(element);
614                                        buffer.setLength(0);
615                                        parseState = 0;
616                                    } else {
617                                        buffer.append(ch);
618                                    }
619                                    break;
620                                case 2:
621                                    if (ch == '"') {
622                                        parseState = 3;
623                                    } else {
624                                        buffer.append(ch);
625                                    }
626                                    break;
627                                case 3:
628                                        if (ch == '\n') {
629                                        result.add(buffer.toString());
630                                        buffer.setLength(0);
631                                        parseState = 0;
632                                        return result;
633                                        } else if (ch == '"') {
634                                        buffer.append('"');
635                                        parseState = 2;
636                                    } else if (ch == ',') {
637                                        result.add(buffer.toString());
638                                        buffer.setLength(0);
639                                        parseState = 0;
640                                    } else if (Character.isSpaceChar(ch)) {
641                                        if (whitespaceSensitive) {
642                                                isEOF = true;
643                                            throw new ParseException("Cannot have trailing whitespace after close quote character", pos);
644                                        }
645                                        parseState = 4;
646                                    } else {
647                                        isEOF = true;
648                                        throw new ParseException("Cannot have trailing data after close quote character", pos);
649                                    }
650                                    break;
651                                case 4:
652                                        if (ch == '\n') {
653                                                // return result so far
654                                                result.add(buffer.toString());
655                                                return result;
656                                        } else if (Character.isSpaceChar(ch)) {
657                                        // consume and ignore
658                                    } else if (ch == ',') {
659                                        result.add(buffer.toString());
660                                        buffer.setLength(0);
661                                        parseState = 0;
662                                    } else {
663                                        isEOF = true;
664                                        throw new ParseException("Cannot have trailing data after close quote character", pos);
665                                    }
666                                    break;
667                                    
668                                default:
669                                    throw new IllegalStateException("Illegal state '" + parseState + "' in parseCsv");
670                            }
671                            
672                                intChar = r.read();
673                                pos++;
674                        }
675                        isEOF = true;
676
677                        // if state is 2, we are in the middle of a quoted value
678                        if (parseState == 2) {
679                            throw new ParseException("Missing endquote in csv text", pos);
680                        }
681
682                        // otherwise we still need to add what's left in the buffer into the result list
683                        element = buffer.toString();
684                        if (parseState == 1 && !whitespaceSensitive) {
685                            element = element.trim();
686                        }
687                        result.add(element);
688                        return result;
689                        }
690        };
691    }
692
693    /**
694     * Equivalent to <code>parseCsv(text, false);</code> (i.e. whitespace-insensitive parsing).
695     * Refer to the documentation for that method for more details.
696     *
697     * @see #parseCsv(String, boolean)
698     *
699     * @param text he CSV-encoded string to parse
700     * 
701     * @return a List of Strings. The returned List is guaranteed to always contain at least one element.
702     *
703     * @throws NullPointerException if the text passed to this method is null.
704     * @throws ParseException see {@link #parseCsv(String, boolean)} for details.
705     */
706    static public List<String> parseCsv(String text)
707        throws ParseException {
708        return Text.parseCsv(text, false);
709    }
710
711    /** Returns a java-escaped string. Replaces '"' with '\"'.
712     *
713     * <p>Since this is predominantly used in the query builder, I am not worrying about
714     * unicode sequences (SWIFT is ASCII) or newlines (although this may be necessary later)
715     * for multiline textboxes
716     *
717     * @return The java-escaped version of the string
718     */
719    public static String escapeJava(String string) {
720        return Text.replaceString(string, "\"", "\\\"");
721    }
722
723    /** Returns a javascript string. The characters <code>'</code>,
724     * <code>"</code> and <code>\</code> are converted into their Unicode equivalents,
725     *
726     * <p>Non-printable characters are converted into unicode equivalents
727     **
728     * <p>Newlines are now replaced with "\n" 
729     *
730     * @return The java-escaped version of the string
731     */
732    public static String escapeJavascript(String string) {
733        // backslashes are always escaped
734        //string = Text.replaceString(string, "\\", "\\u005C");
735        //string = Text.replaceString(string, "\"", "\\u0022");
736        //string = Text.replaceString(string, "'", "\\u0027");
737                //string = Text.replaceString(string, "\n", "\\n");
738        StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder(string.length());
739                for (int i = 0; i<string.length(); i++) {
740                        char ch = string.charAt(i);
741                        if (ch=='\n') {
742                           sb.append("\\n");    
743                        } else if (ch=='\\' || ch=='"' || ch=='\'' || ch<32 || ch>126) {
744                                String hex = Integer.toString(ch, 16);
745                                sb.append("\\u" + "0000".substring(0, 4-hex.length()) + hex);
746                        } else {
747                                sb.append(ch);
748                        }
749                }
750                return scriptPattern.matcher(sb.toString()).replaceAll("\\\\u003C$1");
751        // return sb.toString();
752    }
753
754
755    /** Returns a javascript string. The characters <code>'</code>,
756     * <code>"</code> and <code>\</code> are converted into their Unicode equivalents,
757     *
758     * <p>Non-printable characters are converted into unicode equivalents
759     *
760     * @deprecated use {@link #escapeJavascript(String)} instead
761     * 
762     * @return The java-escaped version of the string
763     */
764    public static String escapeJavascript2(String string) {
765        // this method only exists for backwards-compatability
766        string = reduceNewlines(string);  // canonicalise CRLFs
767        return escapeJavascript(string);
768    }
769
770    
771    /** Unescapes a java-escaped string. Replaces '\"' with '"',
772     * '\\u0022' with '"', '\\u0027' with ''', '\\u005C' with '\'.
773     *
774     * <p>Since this is predominantly used in the query builder, I am not worrying about
775     * unicode sequences (SWIFT is ASCII) or newlines (although this may be necessary later)
776     * for multiline textboxes
777     *
778     * @return The java-escaped version of the string
779     */
780    public static String unescapeJava(String string) {
781        string = Text.replaceString(string, "\\\"", "\"");
782        string = Text.replaceString(string, "\\u0022", "\"");
783        string = Text.replaceString(string, "\\u0027", "'");
784        string = Text.replaceString(string, "\\u005C", "\\");
785        return string;
786    }
787
788    /** Returns a python string, escaped so that it can be enclosed in a single-quoted string. 
789     * 
790     * <p>The characters <code>'</code>,
791     * <code>"</code> and <code>\</code> are converted into their Unicode equivalents,
792     *
793     * <p>Non-printable characters are converted into unicode equivalents
794     *
795     * @return The python-escaped version of the string
796     */
797    public static String escapePython(String string) {
798        // pretty much the same as Text.escapeJavascript2(), without the reduceNewLines, which probably shouldn't be there anyway
799        string = Text.replaceString(string, "\\", "\\u005C");
800        string = Text.replaceString(string, "\"", "\\u0022");
801        string = Text.replaceString(string, "'", "\\u0027");
802                string = Text.replaceString(string, "\n", "\\n");
803                StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder(string.length());
804                for (int i = 0; i<string.length(); i++) {
805                        char ch = string.charAt(i);
806                        if (ch>=32 && ch<=126) {
807                                sb.append(ch);
808                        } else {
809                                String hex = Integer.toString(ch, 16);
810                                sb.append("\\u" + "0000".substring(0, 4-hex.length()) + hex);
811                        }
812                }
813        return sb.toString();
814        // return string;
815    }
816    
817    /** Escape a filename or path component. 
818     * Characters that typically have special meanings in paths (":", "/", "\") are escaped with a preceding "\" character.
819     * 
820     * Does not escape glob characters ( "*" or "?" ). 
821     * Do not use this method to escape a full file path; when escaping a file path, escape each path component separately and then join 
822     * the components with "/" characters ( see {@link #createEscapedPath(String[])} ). 
823     * 
824     * @param string the filename or path component to escape
825     * 
826     * @return the escaped form of the filename (or path component)
827     */
828    // Does not escape DOS special filenames ( "NUL", "CON", "LPT1" etc ). Remember those ? Of course you do.
829    public static String escapePathComponent(String string) {
830        string = Text.replaceString(string, "\\", "\\\\");
831        string = Text.replaceString(string, "/", "\\/");
832        string = Text.replaceString(string, ":", "\\:");
833        return string;
834    }
835    
836    /** Unescape a filename or path component. 
837     * The escape sequences "\\" , "\:" and "\/" are converted to "\", ":" and "/" respectively.
838     * All other escape sequences will raise an IllegalArgumentException 
839     *  
840     * <p>See {@link #splitEscapedPath(String)} to split an escaped path into components. 
841     *  
842     * @param pathComponent the filename or path component to unescape
843     * 
844     * @return the unescaped form of the filename or path component
845     * 
846     * @throws IllegalArgumentException if an unexpected escape is encountered, or the escape is unclosed
847     */
848    public static String unescapePathComponent(String pathComponent) {
849        if (pathComponent == null) {
850            return null;
851        }
852        char c;
853        boolean inEscape = false;
854        StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder(pathComponent.length());
855        for (int i = 0; i < pathComponent.length(); i++) {
856            c = pathComponent.charAt(i);
857            if (inEscape) {
858                switch (c) {
859                        case '\\': 
860                    case '/': // intentional fall-through
861                    case ':': // intentional fall-through
862                        sb.append(c);
863                        break;
864                    default:
865                        throw new IllegalArgumentException("Unexpected escape '\\" + c + "' in filename");
866                }
867                inEscape = false;
868            } else {
869                switch (c) {
870                        case '\\': 
871                                inEscape = true;
872                                break;
873                        default:
874                                sb.append(c);
875                }
876            }
877        }
878        if (inEscape) {
879                throw new IllegalArgumentException("Unclosed escape in filename");
880        }
881        return sb.toString();
882    }
883
884    // need to escape the \ in a regex ( \\ ) in a String ( \\\\ )
885    private static Pattern splitPathPattern = Pattern.compile("(?<!\\\\)/"); 
886    
887        /** Split a path, but allow forward slashes in path components if they're escaped by a preceding '\' character.
888     * Individual path components returned by this method will be unescaped.
889     *
890     * <pre>
891     * splitPath(null) = NPE
892     * splitPath("") = [ "" ]
893     * splitPath("abc") = [ "abc" ]
894     * splitPath("abc/def/ghi") = [ "abc", "def", "ghi" ]
895     * splitPath("abc\\/def/ghi") = [ "abc/def", "ghi" ]
896     * </pre>
897     * 
898     * <p>Opposite of {@link #createEscapedPath(String[])}
899     */
900    public static String[] splitEscapedPath(String escapedPath) {
901        String[] result = splitPathPattern.split(escapedPath);
902        for (int i=0; i<result.length; i++) {
903                result[i] = Text.unescapePathComponent(result[i]);
904        }
905        return result;
906    }
907    
908    /** Escapes the components of a path String, returning an escaped full path String.
909     * Each path component is escaped with {@link #escapePathComponent(String)} and then joined using '/' characters.
910     * 
911     * <p>Opposite of {@link #splitEscapedPath(String)}.
912     * 
913     * @param pathComponents the filename components
914     * @return an escaped path
915     */
916    public static String createEscapedPath(String[] pathComponents) {
917        String result = null;
918        if (pathComponents.length == 0) { 
919                throw new IllegalArgumentException("empty pathComponents"); 
920        }
921        for (String c : pathComponents) {
922                if (c==null) { 
923                        throw new NullPointerException("null pathComponent"); 
924                }
925                if (result == null) {
926                        result = escapePathComponent(c);
927                } else {
928                        result = result + "/" + escapePathComponent(c); 
929                }
930        }
931        return result;
932    }
933    
934    // escapeCss from ESAPI 2.0.1
935    private static final String[] esapi_hex = new String[256];
936        static {
937                for ( char c = 0; c < 0xFF; c++ ) {
938                        if ( c >= 0x30 && c <= 0x39 || c >= 0x41 && c <= 0x5A || c >= 0x61 && c <= 0x7A ) {
939                                esapi_hex[c] = null;
940                        } else {
941                                esapi_hex[c] = toHex(c).intern();
942                        }
943                }
944        }
945        private static String toHex(char c) {
946                return Integer.toHexString(c);
947        }
948        private static String getHexForNonAlphanumeric(char c) {
949                if(c<0xFF) {return esapi_hex[c]; }
950                return toHex(c);
951        }
952    private static String encodeCssCharacter(Character c) {
953                String hex = getHexForNonAlphanumeric(c);
954                if ( hex == null ) { return "" + c; }
955        return "\\" + hex + " ";
956    }
957
958    /**
959     * Returns the CSS-escaped form of a string. 
960     * 
961     * <p>Characters outside of the printable ASCII range are converted to \nnnn form
962     *
963     * @param input the string to convert
964     *
965     * @return the HTML-escaped form of the string
966     */
967    public static String escapeCss(String input) {
968        if (input == null) { return ""; }
969        StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder();
970                for (int i = 0; i < input.length(); i++) {
971                        char c = input.charAt(i);
972                        sb.append(encodeCssCharacter(c));
973                }
974                return sb.toString();           
975    }

980    /** Returns the given string; but will truncate it to MAX_STRING_OUTPUT_CHARS.
981     *  If it exceeds this length, a message is appended expressing how many
982     *  characters were truncated. Strings with the key of 'exception' are
983     *  not truncated (in order to display full stack traces when these occur).
984     *  Any keys that contain the text 'password', 'Password', 'credential' or
985     *  'Credential' will be returned as eight asterisks.
986     *
987     * <p>This method is used in the debug JSP when dumping properties to the user,
988     *  in order to prevent inordinately verbose output.
989     *
990     *  @param key The key of the string we wish to display
991     *  @param string The string value
992     *  @return A (possibly truncated) version of this string
993     */
994    public static String getDisplayString(String key, String string) {
995        return getDisplayString(key, string, MAX_STRING_OUTPUT_CHARS);
996    }
997
998    /** Returns the given string; but will truncate it to MAX_STRING_OUTPUT_CHARS.
999     *  If it exceeds this length, a message is appended expressing how many
1000     *  characters were truncated. Strings with the key of 'exception' are
1001     *  not truncated (in order to display full stack traces when these occur).
1002     *  Any keys that contain the text 'password', 'Password', 'credential' or
1003     *  'Credential' will be returned as eight asterisks.
1004     *
1005     * <p>This method is used in the debug JSP when dumping properties to the user,
1006     *  in order to prevent inordinately verbose output.
1007     *
1008     *  @param key The key of the string we wish to display
1009     *  @param string The string value
1010     *  @param maxChars The maximum number of characters to display
1011     *  
1012     *  @return A (possibly truncated) version of this string
1013     */
1014    public static String getDisplayString(String key, String string, int maxChars) {
1015        if (string == null) {
1016            string = "(null)";
1017        }
1018
1019        if ("exception".equals(key)) {
1020            return string;
1021        }
1022
1023        if (key.indexOf("password") >= 0 || key.indexOf("Password") >= 0 || key.indexOf("credential") >= 0 || key.indexOf("Credential") >= 0) {
1024            return "********";
1025        }
1026
1027        if (string.length() <= maxChars) {
1028            return string;
1029        } else {
1030            return string.substring(0, maxChars) + "... (" + (string.length() - maxChars) + " more characters truncated)";
1031        }
1032    }

1034    /** Utility function to return a default if the supplied string is null.
1035     *  Shorthand for <code>(strText==null) ? strDefaultText : strText;</code>
1036     *
1037     * @return strText is strText is not null, otherwise strDefaultText
1038     */
1039    public static String strDefault(String strText, String strDefaultText) {
1040        return (strText == null) ? strDefaultText : strText;
1041    }

1043    /** Return a string composed of a series of strings, separated with the specified delimiter
1044     *
1045     * @param elements The array of elements to join
1046     * @return delimiter The delimiter to join each string with
1047     *
1048     * @throws NullPointerException if elements or delimiter is null
1049     */
1050    public static String join(String[] elements, String delimiter) {
1051        return joinWithLast(elements, false, delimiter, delimiter);
1052    }
1053
1054    /** Return a string composed of a series of strings, separated with the specified delimiter
1055     *
1056     * @param elements A Collection or Iterable of the elements to join
1057     * @return delimiter The delimiter to join each string with
1058     *
1059     * @throws NullPointerException if elements or delimiter is null
1060     */
1061    public static String join(Iterable elements, String delimiter) {
1062        return joinWithLast(elements, false, delimiter, delimiter);
1063    }
1064    
1065    /** Return a string composed of a series of strings, separated with the specified delimiter.
1066    * Each element is contained in single quotes. The final delimeter can be set to a different
1067    * value, to produce text in the form <code>"'a', 'b' or 'c'"</code> or <code>"'a', 'b' and 'c'"</code>. 
1068    *
1069    * <p>There is no special handling of values containing quotes; see {@link #escapeCsv(String)} 
1070    *
1071    * @param elements The array of elements to join
1072    * @param isQuoted If true, each element is surrounded by single quotes
1073    * @param delimiter The delimiter to join each string with
1074    * @param lastDelimiter The delimiter to join the second-last and last elements
1075    *
1076    * @throws NullPointerException if elements or delimiter is null
1077    */
1078   public static String joinWithLast(String[] elements, boolean isQuoted, String delimiter, String lastDelimiter) {
1079           StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder();
1080       if (elements == null) {
1081           throw new NullPointerException("null elements");
1082       }
1083       if (delimiter == null) {
1084           throw new NullPointerException("null delimiter");
1085       }
1086       if (lastDelimiter == null) {
1087           throw new NullPointerException("null lastDelimiter");
1088       }
1089       int len = elements.length;
1090       if (len == 0) {
1091           return "";
1092       }
1093
1094       for (int i = 0; i < len - 1; i++) {
1095           if (isQuoted) { sb.append("'"); }
1096           sb.append(elements[i]);
1097           if (isQuoted) { sb.append("'"); }
1098           if (i == len - 2) { sb.append(lastDelimiter); } else { sb.append(delimiter); }
1099       }
1100       if (isQuoted) { sb.append("'"); }
1101       sb.append(elements[len - 1]);
1102       if (isQuoted) { sb.append("'"); }
1103       return sb.toString();
1104   }
1105
1106   /** Return a string composed of a series of strings, separated with the specified delimiter
1107    *
1108    * <p>There is no special handling of values containing quotes; see {@link #escapeCsv(String)} 
1109    *
1110    * @param elements A Collection or Iterable containing the elements to join
1111    * @param isQuoted If true, each element is surrounded by single quotes
1112    * @param delimiter The delimiter to join each string with
1113    * @param lastDelimiter The delimiter to join the second-last and last elements
1114    *
1115    * @throws NullPointerException if elements or delimiter is null
1116    *
1117    * @see #join(String[], String)
1118    */
1119   public static String joinWithLast(Iterable<?> elements, boolean isQuoted, String delimiter, String lastDelimiter) {
1120        StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder();
1121       if (elements == null) {
1122           throw new NullPointerException("null elements");
1123       }
1124       if (delimiter == null) {
1125           throw new NullPointerException("null delimiter");
1126       }
1127       if (lastDelimiter == null) {
1128           throw new NullPointerException("null lastDelimiter");
1129       }
1130       Iterator<?> i = elements.iterator();
1131       if (!i.hasNext()) { return ""; } 
1132       
1133       Object thisEl = i.next();
1134       while (i.hasNext()) {
1135           Object nextEl = i.next();
1136           if (isQuoted) { sb.append("'"); }
1137           sb.append(thisEl);
1138           if (isQuoted) { sb.append("'"); }
1139           if (i.hasNext()) {
1140               sb.append(delimiter);
1141           } else {
1142                   sb.append(lastDelimiter);
1143           }
1144           thisEl = nextEl;
1145       }
1146       if (isQuoted) { sb.append("'"); }
1147       sb.append(thisEl);
1148       if (isQuoted) { sb.append("'"); }
1149       
1150       return sb.toString();
1151   }

1155
1156    /*
1157     * efficient search & replace ... stolen from Usenet:
1158     * http://groups.google.co.uk/groups?hl=en&lr=&selm=memo.19990629182431.344B%40none.crap
1159     */
1160
1161    /**
1162     * An efficient search &amp; replace routine. Replaces all instances of
1163     * searchString within str with replaceString.
1164     *
1165     * @param originalString The string to search
1166     * @param searchString The string to search for
1167     * @param replaceString The string to replace it with
1168     *
1169     */
1170    public static String replaceString(String originalString, String searchString, String replaceString) {
1171        if (replaceString == null) {
1172            return originalString;
1173        }
1174
1175        if (searchString == null) {
1176            return originalString;
1177        }
1178
1179        if (originalString == null) {
1180            return null;
1181        }
1182
1183        int loc = originalString.indexOf(searchString);
1184
1185        if (loc == -1) {
1186            return originalString;
1187        }
1188
1189        char[] src = originalString.toCharArray();
1190        int n = searchString.length();
1191        int m = originalString.length();
1192        StringBuilder buf = new StringBuilder(m + replaceString.length() - n);
1193        int start = 0;
1194
1195        do {
1196            if (loc > start) {
1197                buf.append(src, start, loc - start);
1198            }
1199
1200            buf.append(replaceString);
1201            start = loc + n;
1202            loc = originalString.indexOf(searchString, start);
1203        } while (loc > 0);
1204
1205        if (start < m) {
1206            buf.append(src, start, m - start);
1207        }
1208
1209        return buf.toString();
1210    }
1211
1212    /**
1213     * Reads a file, and returns its contents in a String
1214     *
1215     * @param filename The file to read
1216     *
1217     * @return The contents of the string,
1218     *
1219     * @throws IOException A problem occurred whilst attempting to read the string
1220     */
1221    public static String getFileContents(String filename)
1222        throws IOException {
1223        File file = new File(filename);
1224        FileInputStream fis = new FileInputStream(file);
1225        byte[] data = new byte[(int) file.length()];
1226        int len = fis.read(data);
1227        fis.close();
1228        if (len < file.length()) {
1229            /* this should never happen -- file has changed underneath us */
1230            throw new IOException("Buffer read != size of file");
1231        }
1232
1233        return new String(data);
1234    }
1235
1236    /**
1237     * Reads a file, and returns its contents in a String. Identical to calling
1238     * <code>getFileContents(projectFile.getCanonicalPath())</code>.
1239     *
1240     * @param file The file to read
1241     *
1242     * @return The contents of the string,
1243     * @throws IOException 
1244     *
1245     * @throws IOException A problem occurred whilst attempting to read the string
1246     */
1247        public static String getFileContents(File file) throws IOException {
1248                return getFileContents(file.getCanonicalPath());
1249        }

1251    
1252    /**
1253     * Prefixes every lines supplied with a given indent. e.g.
1254     * <code>indent("\t", "abcd\nefgh")</code> would return "\tabcd\n\tefgh". If the
1255     * string ends in a newline, then the return value also ends with a newline.
1256     *
1257     * @param indentString   The characters to indent with. Usually spaces or tabs,
1258     *   but could be something like a timestamp.
1259     * @param originalString The string to indent.
1260     * @return The originalString, with every line (as separated by the newline
1261     *   character) prefixed with indentString.
1262     */
1263    static public String indent(String indentString, String originalString) {
1264        String allButLastChar;
1265        if (originalString == null || indentString == null) {
1266            throw new NullPointerException();
1267        }
1268        if (originalString.equals("")) {
1269            return indentString;
1270        }
1271        allButLastChar = originalString.substring(0, originalString.length() - 1);
1272        return indentString + replaceString(allButLastChar, "\n", "\n" + indentString) + originalString.substring(originalString.length() - 1);
1273    }
1274    
1275    /** Ensure that a string is padded with spaces so that it meets the 
1276     * required length. If the input string exceeds this length, this it 
1277     * is returned unchanged
1278     * 
1279     * @param inputString the string to pad
1280     * @param length the desired length
1281     * @param justification a JUSTIFICATION_* constant defining whether left or 
1282     *   right justification is required.
1283     * 
1284     * @return a padded string. 
1285     */
1286    static public String pad(String inputString, int length, int justification) {
1287        // @TODO not terribly efficient, but who cares
1288        switch (justification) {
1289                case JUSTIFICATION_LEFT:
1290                        while (inputString.length() < length) { 
1291                                inputString = inputString + " ";
1292                        }
1293                        break;
1294
1295                        case JUSTIFICATION_RIGHT:
1296                                while (inputString.length() < length) { 
1297                                        inputString = " " + inputString;
1298                                }
1299                                break;
1300                        
1301                        case JUSTIFICATION_CENTER:
1302                                while (inputString.length() < length) { 
1303                                        inputString = inputString + " ";
1304                                        if (inputString.length() < length) {
1305                                                inputString = " " + inputString;
1306                                        }
1307                                }
1308                                break;
1309        }
1310        return inputString;
1311    }
1312
1313    /** Given a period-separated list of components (e.g. variable references ("a.b.c") or classnames),
1314     *  returns the last component. For example,
1315     *  getLastComponent("com.randomnoun.common.util.Text") will return "Text".
1316     *
1317     *  <p>If component is null, this function returns null.
1318     *  <p>If component contains no periods, this function returns the original string.
1319     *
1320     *  @param string The string to retrieve the last component from
1321     */
1322    static public String getLastComponent(String string) {
1323        if (string == null) {
1324            return null;
1325        }
1326        if (string.indexOf('.') == -1) {
1327            return string;
1328        }
1329        return string.substring(string.lastIndexOf('.') + 1);
1330    }
1331
1332    /** Escape this supplied string so it can represent a 'name' or 'value' component
1333     * on a HTTP queryString. This generally involves escaping special characters into %xx
1334     * form. Note that this only works for US-ASCII data.
1335     *
1336     */
1337    public static String escapeQueryString(String unescapedQueryString) {
1338        // default encoding
1339        byte[] data = encodeUrl(allowed_within_query, unescapedQueryString.getBytes());
1340
1341        try {
1342            return new String(data, "US-ASCII");
1343        } catch (UnsupportedEncodingException e) {
1344            throw new RuntimeException("encodeQueryString() requires ASCII support");
1345        }
1346    }
1347
1348    /**
1349     * Encodes an array of bytes into an array of URL safe 7-bit
1350     * characters. Unsafe characters are escaped.
1351     *
1352     * @param urlsafe bitset of characters deemed URL safe
1353     * @param bytes array of bytes to convert to URL safe characters
1354     * @return array of bytes containing URL safe characters
1355     */
1356    private static final byte[] encodeUrl(BitSet urlsafe, byte[] bytes) {
1357        if (bytes == null) {
1358            return null;
1359        }
1360
1361        if (urlsafe == null) {
1362            throw new NullPointerException("null urlsafe");
1363        }
1364
1365        ByteArrayOutputStream buffer = new ByteArrayOutputStream();
1366
1367        for (int i = 0; i < bytes.length; i++) {
1368            int b = bytes[i];
1369
1370            if (b < 0) {
1371                b = 256 + b;
1372            }
1373
1374            if (urlsafe.get(b)) {
1375                if (b == ' ') {
1376                    b = '+';
1377                }
1378
1379                buffer.write(b);
1380            } else {
1381                buffer.write('%');
1382
1383                char hex1 = Character.toUpperCase(Character.forDigit((b >> 4) & 0xF, 16));
1384                char hex2 = Character.toUpperCase(Character.forDigit(b & 0xF, 16));
1385
1386                buffer.write(hex1);
1387                buffer.write(hex2);
1388            }
1389        }
1390
1391        return buffer.toByteArray();
1392    }
1393
1394    /**
1395     * Encodes a string into Base64 format.
1396     * No blanks or line breaks are inserted.
1397     * @param s  a String to be encoded.
1398     * @return   A String with the Base64 encoded data.
1399     */
1400    public static String encodeBase64(String s) {
1401        return new String(encodeBase64(s.getBytes()));
1402    }
1403
1404    /**
1405     * Encodes a byte array into Base64 format.
1406     * No blanks or line breaks are inserted.
1407     * @param in  an array containing the data bytes to be encoded.
1408     * @return    A character array with the Base64 encoded data.
1409     */
1410    public static char[] encodeBase64(byte[] in) {
1411        int iLen = in.length;
1412        int oDataLen = (iLen * 4 + 2) / 3; // output length without padding
1413        int oLen = ((iLen + 2) / 3) * 4; // output length including padding
1414        char[] out = new char[oLen];
1415        int ip = 0;
1416        int op = 0;
1417
1418        while (ip < iLen) {
1419            int i0 = in[ip++] & 0xff;
1420            int i1 = ip < iLen ? in[ip++] & 0xff : 0;
1421            int i2 = ip < iLen ? in[ip++] & 0xff : 0;
1422            int o0 = i0 >>> 2;
1423            int o1 = ((i0 & 3) << 4) | (i1 >>> 4);
1424            int o2 = ((i1 & 0xf) << 2) | (i2 >>> 6);
1425            int o3 = i2 & 0x3F;
1426            out[op++] = map1[o0];
1427            out[op++] = map1[o1];
1428            out[op] = op < oDataLen ? map1[o2] : '=';
1429            op++;
1430            out[op] = op < oDataLen ? map1[o3] : '=';
1431            op++;
1432        }
1433        return out;
1434    }
1435
1436        /** Used by {@link #parseData(String) to parse dates generated in Codec output.
1437         * (These dates are generated using the standard Java .toString() method, which
1438         * probably changes depending on the VM's locale, which I'm going to ignore for 
1439         * the time being).
1440         */
1441        static class DateParser {
1442                
1443                /** Parse a date generated by Date.toString() into a Date object
1444                 * 
1445                 * @param dateString a string representation of a date
1446                 * @return a Date representation of a date
1447                 */
1448                public static Date valueOf(String dateString) {
1449                        SimpleDateFormat sdf = new SimpleDateFormat("EEE MMM dd hh:mm:ss z yyyy");
1450                        try {
1451                                return sdf.parse(dateString);
1452                        } catch (ParseException pe) {
1453                                throw (IllegalArgumentException) new IllegalArgumentException("Invalid date '" + dateString + "'").initCause(pe);
1454                        }
1455                }
1456        }
1457
1458    // ---------------------- Generous characters for each component validation
1459    // -- not much of this is used in this class, so I should shorten these definitions, 
1460    // but you never know, I might use it later, so it's here for the time being.
1461    // 
1462    // compiled from
1463    //  org.apache.commons.httpclient.util.URIUtil
1464    //  org.apache.commons.codec.net.URLCodec
1465    //  org.apache.commons.httpclient.util.EncodingUtil
1466    //  org.apache.commons.httpclient.URI
1467    //
1468    // trust me... just calling escapeQueryString() is *so* much easier.
1469    private static final BitSet percent = new BitSet(256); // escape % as %25
1470    private static final BitSet digit = new BitSet(256); // 0-9
1471    private static final BitSet alpha = new BitSet(256); // lowalpha | upalpha
1472    private static final BitSet alphanum = new BitSet(256); // alpha | digit
1473    private static final BitSet hex = new BitSet(256); // digit | a-f | A-F
1474    private static final BitSet escaped = new BitSet(256); // "%" hex hex
1475    private static final BitSet mark = new BitSet(256); // -_.!~*'()
1476    private static final BitSet unreserved = new BitSet(256);
1477
1478    // alphanum | mark (URI allowed, no purpose)
1479    private static final BitSet reserved = new BitSet(256); // ;/?:"&=+$,
1480    private static final BitSet uric = new BitSet(256);
1481
1482    // reserved | unreserved | escaped
1483    private static final BitSet allowed_query = new BitSet(256); // uric - %
1484    private static final BitSet allowed_within_query = new BitSet(256);
1485
1486    /** Mapping table from 6-bit nibble to Base64 characters */
1487    private static char[] map1 = new char[64];
1488
1489    // NB: www-form-encoding appears to be alpha | numeric | -_.* ( + space) 
1490    static {
1491        percent.set('%');
1492
1493        for (int i = '0'; i <= '9'; i++) {
1494            digit.set(i);
1495        }
1496
1497        for (int i = 'a'; i <= 'z'; i++) {
1498            alpha.set(i);
1499        }
1500
1501        for (int i = 'A'; i <= 'Z'; i++) {
1502            alpha.set(i);
1503        }
1504
1505        alphanum.or(alpha);
1506        alphanum.or(digit);
1507        hex.or(digit);
1508
1509        for (int i = 'a'; i <= 'f'; i++) {
1510            hex.set(i);
1511        }
1512
1513        for (int i = 'A'; i <= 'F'; i++) {
1514            hex.set(i);
1515        }
1516
1517        escaped.or(percent);
1518        escaped.or(hex);
1519        mark.set('-');
1520        mark.set('_');
1521        mark.set('.');
1522        mark.set('!');
1523        mark.set('~');
1524        mark.set('*');
1525        mark.set('\'');
1526        mark.set('(');
1527        mark.set(')');
1528        reserved.set(';');
1529        reserved.set('/');
1530        reserved.set('?');
1531        reserved.set(':');
1532        reserved.set('@');
1533        reserved.set('&');
1534        reserved.set('=');
1535        reserved.set('+');
1536        reserved.set('$');
1537        reserved.set(',');
1538        unreserved.or(alphanum);
1539        unreserved.or(mark);
1540        uric.or(reserved);
1541        uric.or(unreserved);
1542        uric.or(escaped);
1543        allowed_query.or(uric);
1544        allowed_query.clear('%');
1545        allowed_within_query.or(allowed_query);
1546        allowed_within_query.andNot(reserved);
1547
1548
1549        // excluded 'reserved'                       
1550        // create map1 array
1551        int i = 0;
1552        for (char c = 'A'; c <= 'Z'; c++) {
1553            map1[i++] = c;
1554        }
1555        for (char c = 'a'; c <= 'z'; c++) {
1556            map1[i++] = c;
1557        }
1558        for (char c = '0'; c <= '9'; c++) {
1559            map1[i++] = c;
1560        }
1561        map1[i++] = '+';
1562        map1[i++] = '/';
1563        
1564    }
1565
