1567
1568    /**
1569     * Returns a comparator that compares contained numbers based on their numeric values and compares other parts
1570     * using the current locale's order rules.
1571     * <p>For example in German locale this will be a comparator that handles umlauts correctly and ignores
1572     * upper/lower case differences.</p>
1573     *
1574     * @return <p>A string comparator that uses the current locale's order rules and handles embedded numbers
1575     *         correctly.</p>
1576     */
1577    public static Comparator getNaturalComparator() {
1578        final Collator collator = Collator.getInstance();
1579        return new Comparator() {
1580            public int compare(Object o1, Object o2) {
1581                return compareNatural(collator, (String) o1, (String) o2);
1582            }
1583        };
1584    }    
1585
1586    /**
1587     * <p>Compares two strings using the current locale's rules and comparing contained numbers based on their numeric
1588     * values.</p>
1589     * <p>This is probably the best default comparison to use.</p>
1590     * <p>If you know that the texts to be compared are in a certain language that differs from the default locale's
1591     * langage, then get a collator for the desired locale ({@link java.text.Collator#getInstance(java.util.Locale)})
1592     * and pass it to {@link #compareNatural(java.text.Collator, String, String)}</p>
1593     *
1594     * @param s first string
1595     * @param t second string
1596     * @return zero iff <code>s</code> and <code>t</code> are equal,
1597     *         a value less than zero iff <code>s</code> lexicographically precedes <code>t</code>
1598     *         and a value larger than zero iff <code>s</code> lexicographically follows <code>t</code>
1599     */
1600    public static int compareNatural(Collator collator, String s, String t) {
1601        return compareNatural(s, t, false, collator);
1602    }
1603
1604
1605    /** Natural compare operation. Stolen from 
1606     * http://www.eekboom.com/java/compareNatural/src/com/eekboom/utils/Strings.java
1607     * (source file is under BSD license). 
1608     * 
1609     * @param s             first string
1610     * @param t             second string
1611     * @param caseSensitive treat characters differing in case only as equal - will be ignored if a collator is given
1612     * @param collator      used to compare subwords that aren't numbers - if null, characters will be compared
1613     *                      individually based on their Unicode value
1614     * @return zero iff <code>s</code> and <code>t</code> are equal,
1615     *         a value less than zero iff <code>s</code> lexicographically precedes <code>t</code>
1616     *         and a value larger than zero iff <code>s</code> lexicographically follows <code>t</code>
1617     */
1618    private static int compareNatural(String s, String t, boolean caseSensitive, Collator collator) {
1619        int sIndex = 0;
1620        int tIndex = 0;
1621
1622        int sLength = s.length();
1623        int tLength = t.length();
1624
1625        while(true) {
1626            // both character indices are after a subword (or at zero)
1627
1628            // Check if one string is at end
1629            if(sIndex == sLength && tIndex == tLength) {
1630                return 0;
1631            }
1632            if(sIndex == sLength) {
1633                return -1;
1634            }
1635            if(tIndex == tLength) {
1636                return 1;
1637            }
1638
1639            // Compare sub word
1640            char sChar = s.charAt(sIndex);
1641            char tChar = t.charAt(tIndex);
1642
1643            boolean sCharIsDigit = Character.isDigit(sChar);
1644            boolean tCharIsDigit = Character.isDigit(tChar);
1645
1646            if(sCharIsDigit && tCharIsDigit) {
1647                // Compare numbers
1648
1649                // skip leading 0s
1650                int sLeadingZeroCount = 0;
1651                while(sChar == '0') {
1652                    ++sLeadingZeroCount;
1653                    ++sIndex;
1654                    if(sIndex == sLength) {
1655                        break;
1656                    }
1657                    sChar = s.charAt(sIndex);
1658                }
1659                int tLeadingZeroCount = 0;
1660                while(tChar == '0') {
1661                    ++tLeadingZeroCount;
1662                    ++tIndex;
1663                    if(tIndex == tLength) {
1664                        break;
1665                    }
1666                    tChar = t.charAt(tIndex);
1667                }
1668                boolean sAllZero = sIndex == sLength || !Character.isDigit(sChar);
1669                boolean tAllZero = tIndex == tLength || !Character.isDigit(tChar);
1670                if(sAllZero && tAllZero) {
1671                    continue;
1672                }
1673                if(sAllZero && !tAllZero) {
1674                    return -1;
1675                }
1676                if(tAllZero) {
1677                    return 1;
1678                }
1679
1680                int diff = 0;
1681                do {
1682                    if(diff == 0) {
1683                        diff = sChar - tChar;
1684                    }
1685                    ++sIndex;
1686                    ++tIndex;
1687                    if(sIndex == sLength && tIndex == tLength) {
1688                        return diff != 0 ? diff : sLeadingZeroCount - tLeadingZeroCount;
1689                    }
1690                    if(sIndex == sLength) {
1691                        if(diff == 0) {
1692                            return -1;
1693                        }
1694                        return Character.isDigit(t.charAt(tIndex)) ? -1 : diff;
1695                    }
1696                    if(tIndex == tLength) {
1697                        if(diff == 0) {
1698                            return 1;
1699                        }
1700                        return Character.isDigit(s.charAt(sIndex)) ? 1 : diff;
1701                    }
1702                    sChar = s.charAt(sIndex);
1703                    tChar = t.charAt(tIndex);
1704                    sCharIsDigit = Character.isDigit(sChar);
1705                    tCharIsDigit = Character.isDigit(tChar);
1706                    if(!sCharIsDigit && !tCharIsDigit) {
1707                        // both number sub words have the same length
1708                        if(diff != 0) {
1709                            return diff;
1710                        }
1711                        break;
1712                    }
1713                    if(!sCharIsDigit) {
1714                        return -1;
1715                    }
1716                    if(!tCharIsDigit) {
1717                        return 1;
1718                    }
1719                } while(true);
1720            }
1721            else {
1722                // Compare words
1723                if(collator != null) {
1724                    // To use the collator the whole subwords have to be compared - character-by-character comparision
1725                    // is not possible. So find the two subwords first
1726                    int aw = sIndex;
1727                    int bw = tIndex;
1728                    do {
1729                        ++sIndex;
1730                    } while(sIndex < sLength && !Character.isDigit(s.charAt(sIndex)));
1731                    do {
1732                        ++tIndex;
1733                    } while(tIndex < tLength && !Character.isDigit(t.charAt(tIndex)));
1734
1735                    String as = s.substring(aw, sIndex);
1736                    String bs = t.substring(bw, tIndex);
1737                    int subwordResult = collator.compare(as, bs);
1738                    if(subwordResult != 0) {
1739                        return subwordResult;
1740                    }
1741                }
1742                else {
1743                    // No collator specified. All characters should be ascii only. Compare character-by-character.
1744                    do {
1745                        if(sChar != tChar) {
1746                            if(caseSensitive) {
1747                                return sChar - tChar;
1748                            }
1749                            sChar = Character.toUpperCase(sChar);
1750                            tChar = Character.toUpperCase(tChar);
1751                            if(sChar != tChar) {
1752                                sChar = Character.toLowerCase(sChar);
1753                                tChar = Character.toLowerCase(tChar);
1754                                if(sChar != tChar) {
1755                                    return sChar - tChar;
1756                                }
1757                            }
1758                        }
1759                        ++sIndex;
1760                        ++tIndex;
1761                        if(sIndex == sLength && tIndex == tLength) {
1762                            return 0;
1763                        }
1764                        if(sIndex == sLength) {
1765                            return -1;
1766                        }
1767                        if(tIndex == tLength) {
1768                            return 1;
1769                        }
1770                        sChar = s.charAt(sIndex);
1771                        tChar = t.charAt(tIndex);
1772                        sCharIsDigit = Character.isDigit(sChar);
1773                        tCharIsDigit = Character.isDigit(tChar);
1774                    } while(!sCharIsDigit && !tCharIsDigit);
1775                }
1776            }
1777        }
1778    }
1779
1780
1781        // taken from the W3C Jigsaw server sourcecode; class org.w3c.jigsaw.http.Request#unescape(String)
1782        /**
1783         * Unescape a HTTP escaped string
1784         * @param s The string to be unescaped
1785         * @return the unescaped string.
1786         */
1787        public static String unescapeQueryString (String s) {
1788                StringBuilder sbuf = new StringBuilder() ;
1789                int len  = s.length() ;
1790                int ch = -1 ;
1791                for (int i = 0 ; i < len ; i++) {
1792                        switch (ch = s.charAt(i)) {
1793                                case '%':
1794                                        if (i < len - 2) {
1795                                                // @TODO check to see how illegal escapes are treated
1796                                                // e.g. "%nothex"
1797                                                ch = s.charAt (++i) ;
1798                                                int hb = (Character.isDigit ((char) ch) 
1799                                                          ? ch - '0'
1800                                                          : 10+Character.toLowerCase ((char) ch)-'a') & 0xF ;
1801                                                ch = s.charAt (++i) ;
1802                                                int lb = (Character.isDigit ((char) ch)
1803                                                          ? ch - '0'
1804                                                          : 10+Character.toLowerCase ((char) ch)-'a') & 0xF ;
1805                                                sbuf.append ((char) ((hb << 4) | lb)) ;
1806                                        } else {
1807                                                sbuf.append ('%');  // hit EOL, just leave as is
1808                                        }
1809                                        break ;
1810                                case '+':
1811                                        sbuf.append (' ') ;
1812                                        break ;
1813                                default:
1814                                        sbuf.append ((char) ch) ;
1815                        }
1816                }
1817                return sbuf.toString() ;
1818        }
1819        
1820        /** Returns the largest common prefix between two other strings; e.g. 
1821         * getCommonPrefix("abcsomething", "abcsometharg") would be "abcsometh".
1822         * 
1823         * @param string1 String number one
1824         * @param string2 String number two
1825         * 
1826         * @return the large common prefix between the two strings
1827         * 
1828         * @throws NullPointerException is string1 or string2 is null
1829         */
1830        public static String getCommonPrefix(String string1, String string2) {
1831                if (string1==null) { throw new NullPointerException("null string1"); }
1832                if (string2==null) { throw new NullPointerException("null string2"); }
1833                int c = 0;
1834                int maxLen = Math.min(string1.length(), string2.length());              
1835                
1836                while (c < maxLen && string1.charAt(c)==string2.charAt(c)) {
1837                        c++;
1838                }
1839                return string1.substring(0, c);
1840        }
1841
1842        /** Uppercases the first character of a string.
1843     * 
1844     * @param text text to modify
1845     * 
1846     * @return the supplied text, with the first character converted to uppercase.
1847     */
1848    static public String toFirstUpper(String text) {
1849        return Character.toUpperCase(text.charAt(0)) + text.substring(1); 
1850    }
1851
1852
1853        /** Lowercases the first character of a string.
1854     * 
1855     * @param text text to modify
1856     * 
1857     * @return the supplied text, with the first character converted to lowercase.
1858     */
1859    static public String toFirstLower(String text) {
1860        return Character.toLowerCase(text.charAt(0)) + text.substring(1); 
1861    }

1865    
1866    /** Number of character edits between two strings; taken from  
1867         * http://www.merriampark.com/ldjava.htm. There's a version in commongs-lang,
1868         * apparently, but according to the comments on that page, it uses O(n^2) memory,
1869         * which can't be good.
1870         * 
1871         * @param s string 1
1872         * @param t string 2
1873         *  
1874         * @return the smallest number of edits required to convert s into t 
1875         */
1876        public static int getLevenshteinDistance (String s, String t) {
1877                  if (s == null || t == null) {
1878                    throw new IllegalArgumentException("Strings must not be null");
1879                  }
1880                                
1881                  /*
1882                    The difference between this impl. and the previous is that, rather 
1883                     than creating and retaining a matrix of size s.length()+1 by t.length()+1, 
1884                     we maintain two single-dimensional arrays of length s.length()+1.  The first, d,
1885                     is the 'current working' distance array that maintains the newest distance cost
1886                     counts as we iterate through the characters of String s.  Each time we increment
1887                     the index of String t we are comparing, d is copied to p, the second int[].  Doing so
1888                     allows us to retain the previous cost counts as required by the algorithm (taking 
1889                     the minimum of the cost count to the left, up one, and diagonally up and to the left
1890                     of the current cost count being calculated).  (Note that the arrays aren't really 
1891                     copied anymore, just switched...this is clearly much better than cloning an array 
1892                     or doing a System.arraycopy() each time  through the outer loop.)
1893
1894                     Effectively, the difference between the two implementations is this one does not 
1895                     cause an out of memory condition when calculating the LD over two very large strings.              
1896                  */            
1897                                
1898                  int n = s.length(); // length of s
1899                  int m = t.length(); // length of t
1900                                
1901                  if (n == 0) {
1902                    return m;
1903                  } else if (m == 0) {
1904                    return n;
1905                  }
1906
1907                  int p[] = new int[n+1]; //'previous' cost array, horizontally
1908                  int d[] = new int[n+1]; // cost array, horizontally
1909                  int _d[]; //placeholder to assist in swapping p and d
1910
1911                  // indexes into strings s and t
1912                  int i; // iterates through s
1913                  int j; // iterates through t
1914
1915                  char t_j; // jth character of t
1916
1917                  int cost; // cost
1918
1919                  for (i = 0; i<=n; i++) {
1920                     p[i] = i;
1921                  }
1922                                
1923                  for (j = 1; j<=m; j++) {
1924                     t_j = t.charAt(j-1);
1925                     d[0] = j;
1926                                
1927                     for (i=1; i<=n; i++) {
1928                        cost = s.charAt(i-1)==t_j ? 0 : 1;
1929                        // minimum of cell to the left+1, to the top+1, diagonally left and up +cost                            
1930                        d[i] = Math.min(Math.min(d[i-1]+1, p[i]+1),  p[i-1]+cost);  
1931                     }
1932
1933                     // copy current distance counts to 'previous row' distance counts
1934                     _d = p;
1935                     p = d;
1936                     d = _d;
1937                  } 
1938                                
1939                  // our last action in the above loop was to switch d and p, so p now 
1940                  // actually has the most recent cost counts
1941                  return p[n];
1942        }
1943    
1944        /** Return the md5 hash of a string
1945     * 
1946     * @param text text to hash
1947     * 
1948     * @return a hex-encoded version of the MD5 hash
1949     * 
1950     * @throws IllegalStateException if the java installation in use doesn't know 
1951     *   about MD5
1952     */
1953    static public String getMD5(String text) {
1954        try{
1955                MessageDigest algorithm = MessageDigest.getInstance("MD5");
1956                algorithm.reset();
1957                // algorithm.update(defaultBytes);
1958                algorithm.update(text.getBytes());
1959                byte messageDigest[] = algorithm.digest();
1960                    
1961                StringBuilder hexString = new StringBuilder();
1962                for (int i=0;i<messageDigest.length;i++) {
1963                        hexString.append(Integer.toHexString(0xFF & messageDigest[i]));
1964                }
1965                return hexString.toString();
1966        } catch (NoSuchAlgorithmException nsae) {
1967                throw (IllegalStateException) new IllegalStateException("Unknown algorithm 'MD5'").initCause(nsae);
1968        }
1969    }
1970    
1971    /** Returns a string composed of the supplied text, repeated 0 or more times 
1972     * 
1973     * @param text text to repeat
1974     * @param count number of repetitions
1975     * 
1976     * @return the repeated text
1977     */
1978    static public String repeat(String text, int count) {
1979        StringBuffer sb = new StringBuffer();
1980        for (int i=0; i<count; i++) {
1981                sb.append(text);
1982        }
1983        return sb.toString();
1984    }
1985    
1986    
1987        /** Perform ${xxxx}-style substitution of placeholders in text. Placeholders without 
1988         * values will be left as-is.
1989         * 
1990         * <p>For example, gives the set of variables:
1991         * <ul>
1992         * <li>abc = def
1993         * </ul>
1994         * 
1995         * <p>then the result of <code>substituteParameters("xxxx${abc}yyyy${def}zzzz")</code>
1996         * will be "xxxxdefyyyy${def}zzzz"
1997         * 
1998         * <p><code>$</code> followed by any other character will be left as-is. 
1999         * 
2000         * @param variables a set of variable names and values, used in the substitution 
2001         * @param text the text to be substituted.
2002         * 
2003         * @return text, with placeholders replaced with values in the variables parameter
2004         */
2005        public static String substitutePlaceholders(Map variables, String text) {
2006                // escaped version of (\$\{.*?\}|[^$]+|\$.)
2007                Pattern p = Pattern.compile("(\\$\\{.*?\\}|[^$]+|\\$)"); // modified regex
2008                Matcher m = p.matcher(text);
2009                String result = "";
2010                while (m.find()) {
2011                        String token = m.group(1);
2012                        if (token.startsWith("${") && token.endsWith("}")) {
2013                                Object value = variables.get(token.substring(2, token.length()-1));
2014                                if (value == null) {
2015                                        result = result + token;
2016                                } else {
2017                                        result = result + value.toString();
2018                                }
2019                        } else {
2020                                result = result + token;
2021                        }
2022                }
2023                return result;
2024        }
2025
2026        
2027}
